## Introduction

As humans in a digital society we are living lives that are entwined with technology that exchanges data. We need to exchange data across a myriad of transactions including: to track our businesses, for our communications with friends and family, to come ahead in our educational system, to pay our taxes and many more. We sacrifice our privacy to get access to free applications or to benefit our security [@mckinnon2014sacrificing], or move along faster in a health system [@kernDesigningElectronicPatient2016], or even to register for asylum [@lodinovaApplicationBiometricsMeans2016]. The use of wearables, biometric identification and health monitors have made data flows much more personal, even becoming part of our hormonal cycles and sex life[@gomezortegaDesigningSecondaryUsers2025]. Watches locating children, or apps keeping track of spouses are commonplace, but also form a danger as a "dual-use technology" for malevolent tracking or even surveillance, which itself is a manifestation of inter partner violence [@almansooriGlobalSurveyAndroid2022].

End User License Agreements (EULA's), that require a great deal of surrender of personal information, are signed with a sense apathy and powerlessness [@gomezortegaSurrenderingPowerlesnessGoverning2025; @draperPrivacyResignationApathy2024].

Recent developments have seen generative Artificial Intelligence (genAI) being available for the masses with Large Language Models (LLM's) having a much easier interface for non-technical users. Often signified with the moniker: AI or with magical stars (âœ¨) it features in many applications ranging from web search to [@googleGoogleAIMode;@duckduckgoDuckaiDuckDuckGoHelp; @microsoftIntroducingNewBing] personal communication such as Outlook [@ChatCopilotOutlook] or Whatsapp [@metaMetaAIWhatsApp]. genAI is quickly becoming embedded in all sorts of business and applications [@grantham-philipsAIBecomingIngrained2024].
Even more than in applications beforehand users are encouraged to upload documents and provide more context for the LLM to perform better.

As a result of the increased use of genAI, such as LLM's, a great variety of topics have been researched in the last few years. Such as environmental impact [@dingSustainableLLMServing2024; @rillig2023risks], or a comparison of energy consumption of LLM's vs humans [@ren2024reconciling]. On the other hand the need to improve the environmental impact [@jiangPreventingImmenseIncrease2024; @stojkovic2024towards]. GenAI is also described as both closing and / or widening the digital divide [@carterExploringIntersectionDigital2020; @sartoriMindingGapsPublic2023]. In the context of privacy it seems there is more uncertainty.
